qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: Cost-based pricing implies that price levels of SaaS licenses are defined through cost accounting...cost-based pricing is dictated by SaaS vendors rather than clients. Conversely, value-based pricing of SaaS licenses means that price levels are determined through clients' assessment of the business value
qualitative_analysis.justification: The passage explicitly defines two distinct pricing orientations (cost-based and value-based) as fundamental variations in SaaS business models.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: The largest cluster (C1) makes up 57% of our sample...most SaaS vendors prefer compact licensing models
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes a major subtype where vendors simplify their licensing approach with fewer pricing components.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: Cluster two (C2) makes up 28% of our sample...vendors in C2 attach more importance on value-based rather than cost-based orientation
qualitative_analysis.justification: Identifies a distinct business model variation emphasizing value-based pricing strategy.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: Vendors in Cluster three (C3) that makes up 20% of the sample attach more importance on pricing components from the service-based category
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes a service-focused business model variation with complex licensing approaches.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: Pure SaaS refers to software that is simple to use and has low or no requirements for customization... pure-SaaS products also have lower strategic significance in a customer's business processes
qualitative_analysis.justification: Defines Pure-SaaS as a distinct subtype targeting simpler use cases with lower barriers to change.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: Enterprise-SaaS, on the other hand, refers to software which is more complex and which may require support, involving integration with customers' existing IT systems
qualitative_analysis.justification: Defines Enterprise-SaaS as a variation targeting complex enterprise needs with higher implementation costs and switching barriers.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: SaaS has multi-tenant or multi-instance architecture; the former refers to the situation in which a vendor hosts a single instance on a server that serves multiple customers (tenants), whereas the latter is related to the model in which a vendor hosts separate instances for each customer
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes two fundamental technical architecture variations that enable different business model approaches.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
qualitative_analysis.quote: The resulting strategy is to pursue the so-called hybrid model where both ends (SaaS-based and on-premise products) were handled in equal terms. The distribution of R&D resources was adjusted to 50% each
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes a transitional business model combining cloud and traditional delivery approaches during vendor transformation.

qualitative_analysis.quote: Will that be a pure software product, such as Microsoft Windows; a software–hardware combination (consider the iPhone); or a service, such as eBay?

qualitative_analysis.justification: Identifies four distinct business model archetypes integrating sustainability with different software delivery approaches.

qualitative_analysis.quote: transitioning from the time-tested perpetual licence price model to a cloud and subscription-based pricing model
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes the transition from traditional perpetual licensing to subscription-based cloud model as distinct business model variations.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Navigating the paradox of global scaling
qualitative_analysis.quote: As a variant of a replication strategy labeled flexible replication, this strategy was effective for IKEA
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes variations in how business models are scaled globally with different levels of local adaptation.

qualitative_analysis.justification: Contrasts controlled open platform (Apple) vs. fully open platform (Google) as distinct business model variations.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Open-Source Software Entrepreneurial Business Modelling
qualitative_analysis.quote: Earlier versions of the OSS_EBM framework were introduced in an e-commerce university course...leading to some changes on the OSS_EBM framework till date. Modifying the tool further is currently underway
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes iterative refinement of open source business model framework as it evolves through different versions.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Towards a better Understanding of the Dynamics of Platform as a Service Business Models
qualitative_analysis.quote: The criterion core value proposition is used to describe the main platform offer...Distribution channel describes the case of a company opening its ecosystem...Application-based integration platforms...Platforms dedicated to supporting the entire application or service development process...integration platforms integrate any combination of on-premise and on-demand applications
qualitative_analysis.justification: Identifies four distinct PaaS business model variations based on core value proposition: distribution, application integration, development support, and system integration.
